subject: Cybersecurity
title: Jurisdiction in Cyberspace: Whose Laws Apply Online?
description: A quick, practical guide to Jurisdiction in Cyberspace: Whose Laws Apply Online?.

hook.text: A Russian hacker attacks a French company's server hosted in Ireland, using a VPN in Panama. Whose laws apply?

buildup.text: Physical crimes happen in one place. Cyber crimes cross multiple jurisdictions simultaneously, creating legal chaos.

discovery.text: Countries claim jurisdiction based on where the attacker is, where the victim is, where the server is, or where.

twist.text: Russia and China rarely extradite cybercriminals. Some state-sponsored hackers operate openly, protected by.

climax.text: The internet has no borders. But law enforcement does. This gap is the biggest challenge in prosecuting cybercrime.

punchline.text: The crime was everywhere. The law was nowhere.

quiz.question: Why is jurisdiction a major challenge in cybercrime prosecution?
options: Internet crimes are too small to prosecute
Cyber crimes cross multiple countries simultaneously, and nations disagree on who has authority
There are no international laws about cybercrime
